Description.val:
Calibration Equipment Description:
The objective of the Metrology/Calibration (METCAL) Program is to maintain required accuracy and consistency in Navy measurements.  This ensures the required measurement accuracy of Test and Measurement Systems (TAMS) and Aviation Support Equipment (SE) used to test, repair and maintain Aviation Weapon Systems is adequate.  Calibration is an on-cycle maintenance action and can be described as the comparison of a measurement device/system of unverified/unknown accuracy (TAMS or SE) to a device of known and greater accuracy (Calibration Standard).

Fleet Readiness Centers (FRC) Support Equipment (SE)/Industrial Equipment Description:
The Objective of the FRC SE/Industrial Equipment Investment program is to increase Ready Basic Aircraft (RBA). The purchase of equipment for the Fleet Readiness Centers will increase the agility, capability, and capacity to perform the critical mission of repair, overhaul and modification of aircraft, engines, and components while maintaining the organic industrial capacity to meet current and future requirements.

Justification.val:
Calibration Equipment: 
Funds are used to procure Calibration Standards (CALSTDs) and ancillary equipment for Aviation Fleet Intermediate Calibration Activities, Fleet Training Activities, Aviation Navy Calibration Laboratories (NCLs), and the Navy Primary Standards Laboratory (NPSL).  CALSTDs procured for Fleet 'I' level use are to replace obsolete and/or irreparable equipment, expand technical measurement capabilities to decrease Depot support costs, reduce out-of-service turn around times, provide enhanced forward deployed geographic support and reduce/control the Naval Air Systems Command (NAVAIR) cost of ownership associated with Calibration.   Fleet 'I' level calibration activities support 70% of the total Fleet calibration workload.  Maintenance of Fleet calibration capability through this funding results in the release of more expensive Depot level support man-hours for more complex calibration maintenance and calibrations where economy of scale costs dictate single site or geographic calibration center capability.   CALSTDs procured for NCLs and the NPSL allow for the automation and improvement of calibration procedures in order to reduce Fleet asset out-of-service and Turn around Time, expand technical calibration capabilities for enhanced in-theater Fleet support, and replace obsolete and high support cost CALSTDs.

FRC SE/Industrial Equipment:
There are 71,000 pieces of equipment at the three industrial FRC sites.  59% are greater than 15 years old and 39% are greater than 25 years old.  Capital equipment at the industrial FRCs average more than 25 years in age compared to its 10-year depreciation life.  The APN-7 funding will be used to purchase the equipment necessary to support 4th and 5th generation aircraft and component depot level repairs.

Funding will be used to purchase capital equipment, non-capital equipment, and tooling, replacing obsolete and/or irreparable equipment, expanding technical capabilities decreasing Depot support costs, and reducing out-of-service turnaround times. Equipment investment is an essential element of the 10 to 15-year infrastructure optimization plan in development. The equipment investment plan will move the Depots from an analog to digital infrastructure allowing for increased automation and improvement of procedures increasing capability and production throughput. This funding will help bring the Commander, Fleet Readiness Centers industrial FRC budgets more in-line with the Navy's six percent reinvestment requirement.

Each Cost Element with a Quantity represents a number of different end items.  The Unit Cost is an average cost for all the end items in the Cost element. FY20 increase of 17 units to support 4th and 5th generation aircraft and component depot level repairs.

The totals for Cost Element 1.3 (Equipment Installation) are based on historical values pulled from previous years of Capital Investment Program (CIP) procurement of similar types of  equipment.  Installation cost for equipment projects include minor facilities and utilities modifications and Naval Facilities Engineering Command support costs.

The totals for Cost Element 1.4 (Acquisition Support) are based on historical values pulled from previous years of Capital Investment Program (CIP) procurement of similar types of  equipment. The acquisition support costs are based on estimated average fees for the Contracting Administration entities, such as Defense Logistics Agency, for their efforts with contract award and procurement administrative functions.
